docs.lead_paragraph: Julia Moskin's article last Wednesday about drinking during pregnancy inspired a lot of reader reaction. Here are a few of the letters the Dining section received on the subject. To the Editor: While not denying that drinking may be somewhat risky for pregnant women, I think the medical establishment has gone overboard. Some balance is needed; scientists need to hear from women of my generation who had babies in the 1960s.
docs.abstract: Carol Delaney says medical establishment has gone overboard in telling women never to drink while pregnant; says some balance is called for (Nov 29 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Julia Moskin's article last Wednesday about drinking during pregnancy inspired a lot of reader reaction. Here are a few of the letters the Dining section received on the subject. To the Editor: I'd like to speak for the less-than-five-pound fetus whose mother needs more ''proof'' to completely stop drinking during pregnancy. The mother-to-be likes the authority of the casual obstetrician who supports the ''occasional'' drink, and she particularly likes the bartender who thinks everyone should mind their own business. I wish this mother would think more of the chance she's taking with her fetus, and not make recommendations that may cause others to badly damage their babies through casual drinking.
docs.abstract: Betty Mintz letter says women should think more about fetus than about gratification of casual drinking (Nov 29 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Julia Moskin's article last Wednesday about drinking during pregnancy inspired a lot of reader reaction. Here are a few of the letters the Dining section received on the subject. To the Editor: In 1996, when I was pregnant with my first child, my husband and I set out on a tour of the Italian Piedmont. We visited more than a dozen winemakers; I tasted very judiciously and spat more than I would normally. At mealtime I drank very carefully, never more than a glass per meal.
docs.abstract: Dana S Mermelstein letter describes her experience traveling in Italy and visiting wineries while she was pregnant (Nov 29 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Julia Moskin's article last Wednesday about drinking during pregnancy inspired a lot of reader reaction. Here are a few of the letters the Dining section received on the subject. To the Editor: Any article on alcohol consumption during pregnancy omitting mention of genetics as a factor does a disservice, especially while nodding to ''European dietary traditions.'' Most people are not European and many members of groups highly at risk for fetal alcohol syndrome are not of European descent.
docs.abstract: Letter from Steven Jacquier, doctoral candidate studying fetal alcohol syndrome, says Nov 29 article omits any mention of genetic component as factor
docs.snippet: Julia Moskin's article last Wednesday about drinking during pregnancy inspired a lot of reader reaction. Here are a few of the letters the Dining section received on the subject.    To the Editor:     Any article on alcohol consumption during...

docs.lead_paragraph: Julia Moskin's article last Wednesday about drinking during pregnancy inspired a lot of reader reaction. Here are a few of the letters the Dining section received on the subject. To the Editor: Concerning the dangers of occasionally drinking while pregnant: much of Julia Moskin's piece lauds good old-fashioned common sense over ambiguous clinical data. However, ''common sense'' itself is the reason we have clinical trials. If we were able to deduce all that was healthy or unhealthy to us by mere intuition, we wouldn't need science to begin with. Jacob S. Sherkow Ann Arbor, Mich.
docs.abstract: Jacob S Sherkow letter, prompted by Nov 29 article about pregnant women drinking alcohol, says common sense is no substitute for science
